case_name: Plaintiff v. ex-Ruler of Jaipur and others

facts.text: This is an appeal by the plaintiff against the judgment and decree of the Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, confirming the decree of the trial Judge dismissing the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Hidayatullah, J. This is an appeal by the plaintiff against the judgment and decree of the Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, confirming the decree of the trial Judge dismissing the suit.

facts.text: The suit comes before the Supreme Court on a certificate under Arts. 132(1) and 133(1)(c) of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Rajasthan after the Reorganisation of the States.

anchor.surface_text: It comes before us on a certificate under Arts. 132(1) and 133(1)(c) of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Rajasthan after the Reorganisation of the States.

facts.text: The suit was filed by the appellant for recovery of Rs. 23,998-12-0 as price of goods supplied in the year 1947 to the Ruler of Jaipur State, including interest and damages suffered by the appellant due to the refusal of the defendants to take delivery of some other goods similarly ordered.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed by the appellant for recovery of Rs. 23,998-12-0 as price of goods supplied in the year 1947 to the Ruler of Jaipur State, including interest and damages suffered by the appellant due to the refusal of the defendants to take delivery of some other goods similarly ordered.

facts.text: The suit was filed on February 28, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed on February 28, 1951.

facts.text: Defendants joined: ex-Ruler of Jaipur, his Military Secretary and Mohabat Singh, an employee of the ex-Ruler, on the plea that they placed the orders as agents of the ex-Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the ex-Ruler of Jaipur, his Military Secretary and one Mohabat Singh, an employee of the ex-Ruler, were also joined as defendants, on the plea that they had placed the orders as agents of the ex-Ruler.

facts.text: The ex-Ruler raised the plea that the suit was incompetent as the consent of the Central Government under s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure was not obtained.

anchor.surface_text: The ex-Ruler raised the plea that the suit was incompetent, as the consent of the Central Government under s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure was not obtained and asked that the suit be dismissed.

facts.text: The other defendants denied the claim and their liability on various grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The other defendants denied the claim and also their liability on various grounds.

facts.text: The Military Secretary, second defendant, has since died, and this appeal is not directed against him.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned the Military Secretary second defendant has since died, the this appeal is not directed against the ex-Ruler and Mohabat Singh only.

facts.text: The Subordinate Judge held that the suit was filed prior to the enactment of s. 87-B by s. 12 of the Code of Civil Procedure Amendment Act, 1951 (II of 1951), but could not be continued against the ex-Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that though the suit was filed prior to the enactment of s. 87-B by s. 12 of the Code of Civil Procedure Amendment Act, 1951 (II of 1951), it could not be continued against the ex-Ruler.

facts.text: The Subordinate Judge adjourned the hearing for four months to enable the appellant to obtain the necessary consent.

anchor.surface_text: He adjourned the hearing for four months to enable the appellant to obtain the necessary consent.

facts.text: The appellant applied to the Central Government for consent, but it was refused.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the Central Government for its consent, but it was refused.

facts.text: The appellant applied in revision to the Judicial Commissioner contending that s. 87-B offended Art. 14, but it was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: He also applied in revision to the Judicial Commissioner, contending that s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure offended the equality clause in Art. 14 of the Constitution and was thus void, but the Judicial Commissioner rejected the contention.

facts.text: The Judicial Commissioner refused a certificate on the ground that there was no final order as required by Art. 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: He also refused a certificate on the ground that there was no final order as required by Art. 132(1) of the Constitution.

facts.text: The suit was subsequently dismissed against all three defendants.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was subsequently dismissed against all the three defendants.

facts.text: In regard to the ex-Ruler, the suit was dismissed because no suit lay without consent of Central Government; for remaining defendants, protected by s. 230 of Indian Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the ex-Ruler, it was held that no suit lay against him without the consent of the Central Government, and in regard to the remaining defendants, it was held that they were protected by s. 230 of the Indian Contract Act.

facts.text: Sub-section (3) of s. 230 was held inapplicable as a suit could be filed against ex-Ruler with consent.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (3) of that section was held inapplicable, inasmuch as a suit could be filed against the ex-Ruler with the consent of the Central Government.

facts.text: The appellant appealed to the Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, but the appeal was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appealed to the Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, but the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: The appellant obtained a certificate from High Court of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained a certificate, as stated above, and this appeal has been filed.

facts.text: Mohabat Singh signed letters purporting to emanate from the Military Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: Mohabat Singh, who is the third defendant, cannot be described as an agent of the ex-Ruler, because his connection with the orders placed was merely to sign the letters purporting to emanate from the Military Secretary.

facts.text: Those letters Mohabat Singh signed for the Military Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: Those letters he signed for the Military Secretary.

facts.text: Mohabat Singh was not acting as agent of ex-Ruler but performing ministerial act of signing letters on behalf of Military Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: He was not acting as the agent of the ex-Ruler but was performing the ministerial act of signing the letters on behalf of the Military Secretary.

facts.text: No cause of action against Military Secretary survived as appeal abated against him.

anchor.surface_text: The position of the Military Secretary (since dead) was on a different footing, but it is conceded that no cause of action against him survived, because the appeal has abated against him.

facts.text: Indian States integrated with British India; Rulers and Government of India entered into covenants and agreements.

anchor.surface_text: When the Indian States integrated with British India, the Rulers of States and the Government of India entered into covenants and agreements.

facts.text: In covenants, privileges, dignities and titles of Indian Princes continued to be recognised.

anchor.surface_text: In those covenants, it was agreed that the privileges, dignities and titles of Indian Princes would be continued to be recognised.

facts.text: Code of Civil Procedure Amendment Act, 1951 (II of 1951) enacted s.87-B.

holdings.text: s. 87-B is not ultra vires and void as it does not discriminate in favour of ex-Rulers of Indian States in violation of Art. 14; ex-Rulers form a class based on historical considerations with real and substantial distinction bearing just relation to object of respecting privileges under covenants and Art. 362
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex-Rulers handed over states in return for assurances of personal rights, privileges, dignities including immunity; classification based on historical facts of integration and covenants; Art. 362 mandates due regard; privilege encompasses immunity

holdings.text: The word 'sued' in s. 86(1) read with s. 87-B includes not only initiation but pursuit and continuation of pending suits; consent required for continuation of pending actions against ex-Ruler
holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Sued' means filing, pursuit through courts, entire proceeding; language of sufficient width to rebut presumption against affecting pending actions; no need for express saving clause

holdings.text: The present suit was incompetent against the ex-Ruler of Jaipur without consent of Central Government under s. 87-B

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the present suit was incompetent against the first defendant, the ex-Ruler of Jaipur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies interpretation of 'sued' to facts of pending suit filed before but continued after enactment

holdings.text: Mohabat Singh not liable as he was not agent of ex-Ruler but merely performed ministerial act of signing letters on behalf of Military Secretary
holdings.reasoning_summary: Connection limited to signing letters for Military Secretary; not constituting agency for placing orders

holdings.text: Dismissal of suit against remaining defendants justified as protected under s. 230 Indian Contract Act and no agency established

anchor.surface_text: The suit against him was, therefore, misconceived, whatever might have been said of the Military Secretary. In our opinion, the dismissal of the suit was justified in the circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower court; s.230 applies as principal suable (with consent); no agency for Mohabat Singh

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the dismissal of the suit was justified in the circumstances of the case. The appeal fails, and is dismissed with costs.
